repnme.cdata!: Moldova - Promoting sustainable growth and competitiveness

abstracts.cdata!:
This report talks about the promoting
            sustainable growth and competitiveness in Moldova. Facing
            the need for a sustainable growth strategy, Moldova has been
            working with the International Development Association (IDA)
            to address its main development challenges through increased
            economic competitiveness, promotion of human development and
            social inclusion, and increased effectiveness of the public sector.

docna.cdata!: Moldova - Promoting sustainable growth and competitiveness

display_title.display_title:
Moldova - Promoting sustainable
            growth and competitiveness

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is rated
            highly satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, and
            institutional development impacts substantial, and, the
            Borrower performance is rated highly satisfactory, although
            the Bank performance was just satisfactory. The operation
            consists of a tried-and-proven type of project,
            consequently, there are no radically new lessons that this
            project experience can provide to practitioners,
            researchers, and the international community. However, the
            following elements would be noteworthy. 1) Coalition
            building pays off - i.e., the Government's strong
            commitment and donor support were uninterrupted, even
            increased in spite of the political turmoil, and change of
            government in 2001, delivering the highly satisfactory
            outcome. 2) Good and well-balanced operations management was
            key to effective implementation. While technically and
            conceptually, the project featured no outstanding
            innovation, what the project excelled in however, is that
            all functions within its operation were very well
            balanced-nothing was overdone, there were no noticeable weak
            links in its organization and operation either, resulting in
            high efficiency and effectiveness levels. 3) Strong focus on
            building community-based organizations (CBOs) and their
            networks is key to sustainable institutional development at
            the community level. While this approach is already common
            elsewhere among social investment funds (SIFs), it has
            nonetheless been under-utilized in Europe and Central Asia
            (ECA). But the project proved the validity of this approach,
            through its active support to strengthening CBOs and their
            networks, through the provision of information and resource centers.

repnme.cdata!:
Moldova - Helping pennies add up for a
            village school

abstracts.cdata!:
Ten-year old Valeriu Matran lives in
            Zberoaia, a small village in central Moldova, where winters
            are long, icy and cold. Until recently Valeriu hated to go
            to school, especially during the winter, because classrooms
            were so cold that he had to wear thick warm clothes while in
            class. Although the heat was turned on full blast, he often
            had to blow into his fists to keep his fingers warm because
            he could not write with frozen hands. Due to a lack of
            school space, classes were held in two shiftsone in the
            morning, the other in the afternoon. Classes in the
            afternoon shift had to be shortened by 15-20 minutes so
            students would not be walking home in frigid darkness. When
            this village of 2,000 inhabitants decided to repair the
            school and improve its heating system with the support of
            the World Bank financed Moldova Social Investment Fund,
            Valeriu contributed his modest savings to the village-wide
            campaign to raise additional local funds. By dropping his
            pennies into the communal collection box, traditionally used
            for elections, Valeriu not only contributed to the campaign,
            but also gave it its name. It became known as a penny for
            my school. Two years have passed since repairs were
            completed, and the school is revitalized. Since additional
            classrooms were built, all 310 students go to school in one
            morning shift. Classrooms are bright and warm, yet heating
            costs only $800 compared to $7,000 in previous winters, when
            children were shivering in their coats. Funds were also used
            to buy new school furniture and supplies, including new
            textbooks. Moreover, the school has evolved into a true
            community center whose different activities attract
            inhabitants of all ages, including both Valeriu and his
            grandmother, who is raising him.

Moldova - Helping pennies add up for a
            village school

            FUND PROJECT,TF035555-MOLDOVA - SOCIAL INVESTMENT FUND
5084069.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Rural development,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Investment Fund for Moldova
            aims to a) help empower rural communities by strengthening
            their capacities to make decisions, organize, and manage;
            and b) improve the quality of basic social and economic
            services for rural populations in Moldova, particularly the
            poor. There are three components. The first component
            improves delivery of basic services by rehabilitating
            village and social infrastructure in rural communities
            through micro-projects twinned with programs to improve
            services. The second component leverages project resources
            to finance small innovative micro-project/programs to
            address the programs associated with the
            institutionalization of children and the evolving problems
            of children caused by economic or social dislocations,
            including parental neglect. The third component targets
            community groups, local nongovernmental organizations, local
            contractors, and local government to build capacity in
            skills and relationships, and to foster new
            community-government partnerships in the management of
            social and economic infrastructure.
